As an exhaustive new report sheds light on Huawei's systemic security flaws, Huawei takes out a deceptive ad in the @nytimes calling on Australia to change its 5G policy. This epidemic of paid CCP propaganda in western media has to stop. https://www.nytimes.com/paidpost/huawei/australia-should-reverse-its-huawei-5g-ban.html¬†‚Ä¶

This report should be required reading for anyone making decisions on Huawei and 5G. Threats from Huawei cannot be mitigated, and the sooner the free world unites around the need for a secure 5G supply chain, the better. We must act with a sense of urgency. https://www.wsj.com/articles/huawei-telecom-gear-much-more-vulnerable-to-hackers-than-rivals-equipment-report-says-11561501573?mod=searchresults&page=1&pos=7¬†‚Ä¶

We expect transparency in our everyday lives, and we should demand the same in healthcare. Clear and easy-to-understand pricing will increase competition and lower healthcare costs, and I believe bipartisan bills I introduced like H.R. 1409 will help do just that.

As with any other purchase, patients should be able to compare prices to make the best choice for themselves and their families. I've long worked to improve healthcare price transparency and empower consumers, and wrote about some of these ideas here: https://gallagher.house.gov/media/columns/rep-gallagher-americans-deserve-transparency-healthcare-providers¬†‚Ä¶

THREAD ‚û°Ô∏è This is great news. I applaud the President‚Äôs efforts and look forward to working with the Administration to help lower healthcare costs. https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-to-issue-executive-order-on-health-care-price-transparency-11561051500¬†‚Ä¶

This is ultimately a test of the NSS/NDS: can we deter our second/third tier enemies in the Middle East with relatively fewer resources (i.e. play moneyball), without getting blown off course on the greater long term challenge: strategic competition with China?

There are a host of options stronger than sanctions but less escalatory than attacking SAM sites and killing 150 Iranians. Proportionality shouldn‚Äôt unnecessarily constrain us from multiple low-cost options available to restore deterrence without inexorably spiraling into war.

A few thoughts in light of the current crisis: 

A response is necessary and warranted. Iran has attacked six tankers, two pumping stations, a Saudi airport, US facilities in Iraq, and a US drone. Doing nothing only increases the likelihood of further aggression and blackmail.

Looking forward to discussing the crisis in Xinjiang and why we need to elevate human rights concerns in our relationship with China. Ideological competition is just as important as our military and economic competition with the CCP. https://twitter.com/JohnHemmings2/status/1141771816832290816¬†‚Ä¶

Yesterday marked the 40th anniversary of the VA Readjustment Counseling Service and 40 years of incredible service to NEW veterans. Coming home from service is never easy, but the Vet Center in Green Bay helps our veterans & their families navigate an otherwise trying time.

Traumatic experiences impact children, adults, & vets across the country. We need a strong trauma-informed workforce to help those impacted by trauma, & this week I introduced a bill with @RepDannyDavis to ensure communities have the resources to do so. https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-gallagher-colleagues-introduce-legislation-supporting-trauma-informed-care¬†‚Ä¶

30 years ago, the CCP presided over the Tiananmen massacre. We cannot let that happen in Hong Kong. 

From reassessing the Hong Kong Policy Act to Magnitsky sanctions on senior leaders, we have a variety of options. We must use them to defend what remains of freedom in Hong Kong.

As Eisenhower said before the battle, "the eyes of the world are upon you. The hopes and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you." 

75 years ago, these men rose to the challenge, and we're free because of their heroism and sacrifice.  #DDay75thAnniversary

I want to thank the @WisVetsMuseum for sharing some of the photos and stories above, and for their commitment to honoring Wisconsin‚Äôs veterans. It‚Äôs important for us all to continue telling our veterans‚Äô stories of courage.

Robert Reeners of Hobart piloted a boat filled with troops and supplies onto Utah Beach. He survived near misses from a German fighter pilot and later from German artillery guns, and recalled ‚ÄúThe air was just black with planes. Fighters, bombers and planes towing gliders." pic.twitter.com/ofyUygIqna

Norman C. Herro, a Milwaukee native, served as a navigator on a C-47aircraft in the Army Air Forces. Herro was tasked with dropping the first wave of American troops behind enemy lines to serve as a guide for the thousands more that would follow on the beaches. pic.twitter.com/18nR54jPcp

Raymond Skaleski of Brown County landed on Omaha Beach, and his company would provide critical support to other infantrymen as they stormed inland. He died of wounds suffered on D-Day and earned a Silver Star and Purple Heart for his courage. pic.twitter.com/lF8OWN27SW

Billy Hahnen served as a paratrooper during WWII, where he helped disrupt German communications and cleared the way for the D-Day landings. He continued to serve his country after D-Day and would earn the Silver Star, Bronze Star, and the Purple Heart for his service. pic.twitter.com/TeUWp3GthH

THREAD ‚Üí 75 years ago, nearly 160,000 brave allied soldiers stormed the beaches and hedgerows of Normandy and paved the way for the liberation of Europe. Today I want to recognize some of the many Wisconsinites whose heroism and sacrifice contributed to this historic effort. pic.twitter.com/wu4oOrpkyE

But what we often forget is that Eisenhower simultaneously wrote a letter taking the blame should the operation fail. He was prepared to shoulder the burden and accept responsibility, which is not just a great lesson in leadership, but one of the many reasons why I admire Ike.

I have a copy of that letter hanging in my office. It serves as a reminder of his aspirational leadership and of the brave soldiers who lost their lives fighting for ‚Äúthe elimination of Nazi tyranny...and security for ourselves in a free world." pic.twitter.com/rUvR0Ec4JO

THREAD ‚û°Ô∏è 75 years ago today, General Eisenhower wrote a letter to the 160,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen who would fight in the decisive battles on the beaches and in the hedgerows of Normandy. Their efforts would go down in history, as would General Eisenhower‚Äôs leadership.
